title: 115_hr68
content: The Act is titled the "Tiffany Joslyn Juvenile Accountability Block Grant Program Reauthorization Act of 2017" and it reauthorizes the Juvenile Accountability Block Grant Program. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include graduated sanctions and incentives, remove certain paragraphs, and update interventions for bullying prevention programs. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include interventions like anti-bullying programs, mental health services, and trauma-informed practices. Amendments also involve adding incentives to individualized sanctions and expanding the range of court-approved interventions for sanctions. The amendments to the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 include adding incentives as individualized responses to juvenile offenders' compliance with court orders and case disposition terms. Incentives may include certificates of achievement, letters of recommendation, family or program activities, meetings with community leaders, and reductions in community service hours or curfew restrictions. The amendments to the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 introduce incentives for juvenile offenders' compliance with court orders, such as certificates of achievement, letters of recommendation, family activities, and reduced community service hours or curfew restrictions. Additionally, there are changes in funding allocation for fiscal year 2020. SEC. 1811 introduces grant accountability measures. SEC. 1811 introduces grant accountability measures, defining applicable committees as the Senate and House Committees on the Judiciary. Grants awarded by the Attorney General must adhere to accountability provisions, including an audit requirement for unresolved audit findings. Beginning in the first fiscal year after enactment, the Inspector General of the Department of Justice will conduct audits of grant recipients to prevent misuse of funds. Recipients with unresolved audit findings will be ineligible for grant funds for the following two fiscal years. The Attorney General will prioritize eligible applicants without unresolved audit findings in the 3 fiscal years before applying for a grant. If an entity receives grant funds while barred from receiving grants, the improperly awarded amount will be deposited into the General Fund. The Attorney General will prioritize eligible applicants without unresolved audit findings in the 3 fiscal years before applying for a grant. Improperly awarded grant funds will be deposited into the General Fund for repayment, and annual certifications will be submitted to ensure completion of audits. Before awarding a grant, the Attorney General must ensure that all mandatory exclusions and reimbursements have been issued. A list of excluded grant recipients from the previous year must also be included. To prevent duplicative grants, the Attorney General will compare potential grant awards to avoid awarding duplicate grants for the same purpose to the same applicant. The Attorney General must report to committees on any duplicate grants awarded under this part, including the total amount and the reason for awarding them. The Congress encourages the use of best practices for grants under part R of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. Section 609Y(a) of the Justice Assistance Act of 1984 is amended to extend emergency federal law enforcement assistance until September 30, 2023.
